attributes.action: support the erection of a statue in Margate Harbour to commemorate Shackleton's Endurance expedition
attributes.action_prefix: We the undersigned petition the Prime Minister to
attributes.background:
A few days in Margate played a pivotal role in the Endurance Expedition - the most celebrated of the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration. Shackleton explains: "On Sunday afternoon [August 3, 1914] I took [Endurance] off Margate, growing hourly more anxious as the ever–increasing rumours [of war] spread; and on Monday morning I went ashore and read in the morning paper the order for general mobilization. I immediately went on board and... proposed to send a telegram to the Admiralty offering [our] services to the country in the event of war breaking out. All hands immediately agreed, and I sent off a telegram in which everything was placed at the disposal of the Admiralty... Within an hour I received a laconic wire from the Admiralty saying "Proceed." Within two hours a longer wire came from Mr Winston Churchill, in which we were thanked for our offer, and saying that the authorities desired that the Expedition… should go on."
A statue in Margate Harbour of Sir Ernest Shackleton, perhaps with a newspaper displaying the portentous headline, would suitably commemorate, and evoke the intense drama of, a critical moment in an expedition written large in British history.
